description: Content that uses alternative history, architectural conspiracies (e.g., Tartaria, Mud Flood), or 'hidden past' narratives as a Trojan horse to funnel users toward white supremacy, anti-institutional extremism, antisemitism, or sovereign citizen ideologies. This category targets content that evades political extremism filters by masquerading as educational or historical analysis.

co_occurrence_signals.note: Severity increases when architectural/historical keywords co-occur with supremacist, anti-institutional, or 'cabal' rhetoric.

language_evasion_flag.note: Threat actors frequently translate these concepts into Russian or Ukrainian to bypass English-centric political extremism filters while maintaining the same visual and structural payloads.

visual_signals.note: These are common visual motifs used in the 'normiefication' of this content.
motifs: side-by-side comparisons of classical vs brutalist architecture
sepia-toned photos of 19th-century cities with 'empty streets'
highlighting basement windows as 'proof' of mud flood

channel_signals.note: These are content-pattern signals, not targeting any specific group

safe_harbor: Academic or educational discussion of the Tartaria conspiracy theory as an internet phenomenon
Genuine architectural history channels discussing the demolition of Penn Station or the Singer Building without conspiracy framing
debunk_searches: real history vs conspiracy theories critical thinking
